1.action:
Prepare kernel, rootfs tar.bz2 image, and qemu configuration  
    	a. Download kernel, rootfs tar.bz2 image and qemu configuration from public autobuilder webpage  
    	b. Goto https://autobuilder.yocto.io/pub/releases//machines/qemu/qemux86/ 
    	c. Download  
    	  	i. rootfs tar.bz2: core-image-sato-sdk-qemux86.tar.bz2 
      		ii. kernel: bzImage-qemux86.bin 
      		iii. qemu configuration: core-image-sato-sdk-qemux86.qemuboot.conf

2.action:
Download & install sdk toolchain from public autobuilder 
    	a. Goto https://autobuilder.yocto.io/pub/releases//toolchain/x86_64/ 
    	b. Download poky-glibc-x86_64-core-image-sato-sdk--toolchain-.sh 
    	c. Run command: poky-glibc-x86_64-core-image-sato-sdk--toolchain-.sh

3.action:
Extract rootfs twice into two images 
    	a. Run 2 commands below:  
                  runqemu-extract-sdk core-image-sato-sdk-qemux86.tar.bz2 qemux86_rootfs_image1  
                  runqemu-extract-sdk core-image-sato-sdk-qemux86.tar.bz2 qemux86_rootfs_image2

4.action:
From the 2 terminals, start qemu to boot up both two images 
    	a. Run 2 commands below:  
                  runqemu core-image-sato-sdk-qemux86.qemuboot.conf qemux86_rootfs_image1  
                  runqemu core-image-sato-sdk-qemux86.qemuboot.conf qemux86_rootfs_image2
4.expected_results: Expect qemu to boot up successfully.
